user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_GenericClose_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_GenericClose_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int                             result;
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);

    result = close(impl->fd);
    if (result < 0)
    {
        /*
         * close() can technically fail for various reasons, but
         * there isn't much recourse if this call fails.  Just log
         * the failure for debugging.
         *
         * POSIX also does not specify the state of the filehandle
         * after a close() with an error.
         *
         * At least in  Linux/glibc the filehandle is always closed
         * in the kernel and should not be used again or re-closed.
         */
        OS_DEBUG("close: %s\n", strerror(errno));
    }
    impl->fd = -1;
    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_GenericClose_Impl:
#define OS_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) 
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
typedef struct
{
    int  fd;
    bool selectable;
} OS_impl_file_internal_record_t
...
extern OS_impl_file_internal_record_t OS_impl_filehandle_table[OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES]
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The only use of a standard-string-library function in the provided code is the call to strerror inside the OS_DEBUG call. No other calls to <string.h> functions (e.g. memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn, etc.) appear in the target function or related definitions shown. The other statements (impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(...), result = close(impl->fd); impl->fd = -1; return OS_SUCCESS;) do not invoke string.h functions and therefore are not relevant to MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17. The OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET/OS_ObjectIndexFromToken macro usage involves integer indexing and pointer arithmetic for object lookup, not string operations, so it does not need investigation under this rule. If the OS_DEBUG macro is disabled (as shown), the strerror call is not evaluated at runtime, but the call site should still be inspected because enabling/logging variants could re-enable the string usage.
